content.question: A long platform of negligible mass rests on two supports, one at each end, as shown in the figures. Two identical blocks can be placed on the platform in the three different arrangements shown, with each block always placed either directly over a support or halfway between the supports. How do the upward forces <math alttext="F sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="F sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, and <math alttext="F sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> exerted by the right-hand support on the platform compare for the three arrangements?

choices.label: <math alttext="F sub 1 equals F sub 2, which equals F sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>

<math alttext="F sub 1 is greater than F sub 2, which is greater than F sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>

<math alttext="F sub 2 equals F sub 3, which is greater than F sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="F sub 2 is greater than F sub 3, which is greater than F sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="F sub 2 equals F sub 3, which is greater than F sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

topic.text: 5.5: Rotational Equilibrium and Newton's First Law in Rotational Form

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
